awd_titl_txt: Multi-Scale Models for Membrane Fission Catalyzed by the Endosomal Sorting Complexes Required for Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
Membranes adopt a broad range of shapes to facilitate specific and central functions at the level of cells and organelles. Proteins and lipids play a key role in this process, but their molecular choreography is still emerging and their impact on altering membrane shape in vivo remains controversial and obscure. A central challenge in cell biology is to understand the molecular mechanisms by which intracellular membranes are shaped by proteins. Deciphering these mechanisms, through mathematical modeling and analysis, molecular simulations, and integration with new experimental efforts, will revolutionize our view of biology and provide opportunities for engineering that extend the limitations of natural biological systems.

This project tightly integrates mathematical theory (Spagnolie), molecular simulations at atomistic and coarse-grained levels (Cui), and biochemical and functional experimental approaches (Audhya) to decipher the mechanism of membrane fission catalyzed by the ESCRT complexes. The mathematical analysis and modeling at the continuum level goes beyond previous continuum models to explicitly include the energetic and dynamic features of ESCRT-III filaments and their interactions with the multi-component membrane and nearby solvent. Molecular simulations at atomic and coarse-grained levels provide realistic estimates of mechanical and dynamic properties of proteins and membrane required in the mathematical analysis. Numerical simulations and asymptotic analysis will identify the physical properties of ESCRT-III subunits and their interactions with the membrane that drive membrane vesiculation, leading to specific predictions (mutations) that will be tested in the Audhya lab. Results of experimental tests feed back to the calibration and refinement of the mathematical models and molecular simulations. The iterative process that integrates multi-scale computations and experimental investigation will establish a powerful paradigm to advance our mechanistic understanding of complex biological processes.

por.por_cntn:
With the funding provided by this grant the Audhya, Cui, and Spagnolie groups set out to explore fundamental physics and biology relevant to membrane remodeling by biofilaments, in particular the ESCRT-III (Endosomal sorting complexes for transport-III) machinery. CRISPR-mediated genome editing offered a means of knocking out ESCRT-III subunits, and provided a way to explore defects in ESCRT machinery functions. Numerous subsequent findings highlighted critical roles for the ESCRT machinery, not only in the maintenance of inner nuclear membrane morphology, but also in growth factor signaling and association/dissociation of the ESCRT complexes to and from endosomal membranes. Continuum modeling was used to derive equations governing orientable membrane-bound biofilaments, and a numerical code was written to study the fully coupled system of ESCRT-III machinery and deformable membranes. Exact solutions for filament configurations were found for membranes of constant background curvature, and numerical difficulties with finite-end boundary conditions were overcome which retain high-order accuracy. The continuum approach, fully transferable, was also used to examine active semi-flexible biofilaments in other contexts including self-buckling and self-writhing of swarmer P. mirabilis cells, and informed additional analytical results on the stability of thin bands of active suspensions and bifurcations in multicomponent membrane shapes in dynamic environments. Molecular dynamics simulations were used to extract more precisely the material properties of the ESCRT-III complex and its energetic relation to membrane curvature on atomistic and coarse-grained levels. Detailed observations of membrane bending upon the introduction of ESCRT-III also pointed to wider discrepancies in commonly used simulation approaches - different coarse-grained models in fact may lead to qualitatively different membrane curvature. The tools developed allowed for the inspection of membrane remodeling by other proteins. Membrane curvature generation by transmembrane proteins, and transmembrane reorganization, were additional dimensions explored.
